abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Emergency Recovery
            Credit (ECR) Project for Rwanda were as follows: outcomes
            were satisfactory, project sustainability was uncertain,
            Bank performance was satisfactory and Borrower performance
            was also a satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: the
            design of emergency operations should be kept simple, and
            particularly avoid operational conditions for effectiveness.
            Conditions that are essential for the operation of the
            credit should be conditions for board presentation. It is
            important to gauge the government's capacity and
            commitment, in order to design an operation that responds
            effectively the realities in the country. Deep understanding
            of politically sensitive issues by the Bank, and
            International Development Association (IDA) and donor
            procedures by the Borrower, are important for the Bank and
            the Borrower to understand each other and work well
            together. The ECR served as a catalyst for providing funding
            for the reconstruction of Rwanda and encouraged
            burden-sharing among donors. As such, it represented an
            important part of a broad-based international rescue effort;
            however, there was a lack of coordinated effort to raise the
            additional resources required for an effective recovery program.
